docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: David Frum (Op-Ed, April 2) has a difficult time making a case against the Hatch-Kennedy proposal to give states $5 billion a year to subsidize health coverage for children who lack insurance. He keeps agreeing with the goals of the bill while arguing that it wouldn't be as ''helpful as it seems.'' Mr. Frum's real objection can only be stated in the most oblique terms because the Republican Party has got little political mileage with its basic premise that competition is valuable in all pursuits, economic and social.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''What's Wrong With This Plan?'' (Op-Ed, April 2), David Frum chooses an interesting metaphor when he equates stripped-down health care and a Model T Ford. If Ford had improved the Model T over the years, it probably would not have dropped behind General Motors. It was Henry Ford's resistance to improvements like hydraulic brakes and the six-cylinder engine that paved the way for G.M. Ford's original goal of creating a product for the working man is one the health care industry and Congress should adopt.

docs.lead_paragraph: The John Alden Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 725 jobs this year to cut costs and focus on its group health insurance and managed-care businesses. About 250 of the jobs being cut are in annuity and credit card businesses, which John Alden, an insurance company based in Miami, is leaving. The other 475 job cuts, representing 20 percent of the company's remaining staff, are ''a necessary step in successfully positioning this company for the future,'' its chief executive said. The company said it would take a $15 million charge against earnings for the cost of dismissing workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: For conservatives, the performance of the Republican Congress is rapidly deteriorating from the depressing to the embarrassing. Each week we wonder, can things get worse? And the answer always seems to be, yes, they can. Now Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah has unveiled a plan to give the Government an even greater role in health care. Senator Hatch and his Democratic co-sponsor, Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, propose to give states up to $5 billion a year to subsidize health coverage for children who lack insurance but whose parents earn too much to qualify for Medicaid. The Senators would raise the money by increasing the Federal tax on cigarettes by 43 cents a pack.

docs.lead_paragraph: An unusual alliance of prominent business groups, welfare advocates and county officials has called on state leaders to go beyond Gov. George E. Pataki's welfare overhaul plan in guaranteeing child support collections, day care, health coverage, transportation and other services for people moving from welfare to work. The Business Council of New York State and the National Federation of Independent Business have joined in a nine-page statement that urges the state to increase spending , perhaps by as much as $200 million a year, to help welfare recipients find and keep jobs. Also signing the statement were the League of Women Voters; the State Association of Counties; the State Communities Aid Association, which is a leading welfare advocacy group; the New York State Child Care Coordinating Council, and the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Agents with the Federal Bureau of Investigation are examining the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's deals to acquire control of certain hospitals in northeastern Ohio, people with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday. The inquiry comes amid growing Federal scrutiny of the company and its business practices. But the examination by Federal agents in Ohio, a state that has been a flashpoint for criticism about certain of the company's deals, takes the active Federal inquiries into a new area: How the company has acquired its assets.
